botanical_details.potentially_harmful: Contact may irritate the skin. Wear gloves and other protective equipment when handling
botanical_details.genus: Hydrangea can be deciduous or evergreen shrubs, or self-clinging climbers, with flowers in clusters usually comprising both small fertile and more showy sterile flowers; often good autumn colour

how_to_grow.cultivation: Thrives in humus rich soil, that is consistently moist but not waterlogged. Position in sun or part-day shade; in warmer areas, plants may benefit from shade from hot afternoon sun. Mulch in spring, and provide shelter from cold, drying winds. See shrubby hydrangea cultivation for more detailed advice
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by softwood cuttings in early summer, or by hardwood cuttings in winter
how_to_grow.pruning: Cut back to a framework in spring; see pruning group 4 (hydrangeas) for more detailed advice
how_to_grow.pests: May be susceptible to aphids, capsid bug, red spider mite, stem and bulb eelworm, vine weevil and scale insects
how_to_grow.diseases: May be susceptible to honey fungus, grey moulds, powdery mildews, leaf spot and virus diseases
